title.narrative: Rivers Coalition in Cambodia Proj- NGOF

description.narrative:
The establishment of the Rivers Coalition in Cambodia (RCC) was the culmination of several years of collaboration, bringing Cambodian and international NGOs to work together. This collaboration was centred on environmental and human rights issues relatedto hydropower dam development projects on first the Sesan River, then the Srepok and Sekong Rivers (the 3S Rivers) and most recently, on dam-related issues affecting Cambodia. Previously, the name of this coalition was the Sesan Working Group (2003-05),which was established by various NGOs to support dam-affected communities on the Sesan River. With the addition of new NGO members and the expansion of geographical scope, the coalition became the 3S Working Group (2005-06). Today, the name has changedtoreflect the growing dam-related issues faced throughout Cambodia.
IP2 will support RCC in its implementation of key activities to: promote policy dialogue, influence the hydropower dam development process to hold the government and developers accountable, raise awareness and build capacity among its members, support research, produce influencing material on hydropower projects and its impacts. This aligns with objective number 2 of Oxfam#s Mekong Regional Water Governance Program and Inclusion Project that hold infrastructure developers accountable and promote standards. Moreover, this isconsistent with Oxfam in Cambodia#s Natural Resources Governance Program objective number 2 to improve and enforce relevant government laws and policies in accordance to international principles and standards related to natural resources governance. IP2 will enable RCC and its members to actively engage with sub-national, national and regional partnersto influence transboundary policy improvement on water governance in Cambodia and the greater Mekong region, while ensuring the meaningful engagement and participation of communities in the development consultation process. The RCC will also be contributing to the planning and implementation of awareness raising and advocacy activities on gender issues in response to Cambodia#s energy planning and hydropower development .

participating-org.narrative:
The NGO Forum was started in Cambodia in the 1980s by international NGOs who wanted to put an end to Cambodia's international isolation and aid embargo. In the 1990s, as Cambodia opened up to the world, the NGO Forum became Cambodia-based, and began to invite local organisations to join as members. Nevertheless, it was still governed by an international Steering Committee and dominated by international NGOs right up to 1996. In 1997 a clear decision was made to make the NGO Forum more relevant to the concerns of the Cambodian people, resulting in an expansion of the membership base among local NGOs. A new expatriate representative was recruited and given the mandate to transition the NGO Forum towards full Cambodian leadership. Cambodian staff members began to play dominant roles in NGO Forum activities, and the first fully Cambodian Management Committee was elected in 2000. Over the course of the next eight years, the NGO Forum grew to respond to a number of emerging critical issues affecting poor and vulnerable communities across Cambodia.
The NGO Forum on Cambodia is a membership organisation for local and international NGOs based in Cambodia. It exists for the purpose of information sharing, debate and advocacy on priority issues affecting Cambodia's development. It aims to represent the viewsof the NGO community to decision-makers on issues such as development policy (overall economic and political issues), gender mainstreaming, and environmental protection and land rights. Presently the NGO Forum on Cambodia registers 79 full members and two associate members. Of the 79 full members, 46 are local NGOs and 33 are international NGOs.
